It flies off towards the inner city if reduced to less than half its hit points. Manticores in the Inner City may hunt in packs of 5 ([[/r 2d4]]).

Old Alchemist's Shop. A decrepit alchemist's shop that reeks of a chemical odor stands on a street corner. A pool of spilled chemicals has become an aggressive @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.xBhG7Dos3tkg9jWz]. In the Inner City, 2 ([[/r 1d4]]) @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.NwQpeeaMxAC3fRft]{Black Puddings} are encountered instead.

Overgrown Ruin. Strange alien plants and oddly-shaped vines creep up a crumbling ruin. A @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.gGeLeV411iQ5Yijs] and 2 ([[/r 1d4]]) @UUID[Actor.JOQZAx77IIbznFVO]{Hypnotic Eldritch Blossoms} grow in the tangled mass.

Phase Webs. Strange webs cover this section of the ruins and fill nearby buildings - some even span the streets themselves. 2 ([[/r 1d4]]) @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.llSG0Hi4eGlRlQ4o]{Phase Spiders} resting in the dark corners come to investigate any disturbance of their webs. The webs are especially thick in regions of the Inner City, where there are 7 ([[/r 2d6]]) @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.28gU50HtG8Kp7uIz]{Spiders} instead.

Pilgrims of the Falling Fire. A group of 10 ([[/r 3d6]]) @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.qkLNA1lKMMJpxuWg]{Cultists} led by a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.tYfQIxCJT0WaaKmc] and a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.kz1t6xeXVwODpYb2] are heading towards the Crater.

Queen's Men Looters. 7 ([[/r 2d6]]) @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.n4TEv7inVUkyZviN]{Bandits} led by a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.rb7OJt822wIO52qY] are hoping for easy pickings. The bandits try to hide from the players until they appear wounded or in need of a rest, so canny characters might spot them before this happens.

Questing Knight. A Silver Order @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.D5UqYD1EnTrJaMTO] on a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.T1xZTDCGuvMBSq8d] with a retinue of 7 ([[/r 2d6]]) @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.E9CvDPDg5dFEpVjS]{Guards} are searching for lost relics and holy sites in the ruins.

Ratling Raiders. A ratling @UUID[Actor.N47wmcUojv25nJTo] leads a great horde of 21 ([[/r 6d6]]) @UUID[Actor.v6osXCahFwmobuQz]{Ratlings}.

Ratling Scavengers. 10 ([[/r 3d6]]) @UUID[Actor.v6osXCahFwmobuQz]{Ratlings} hide down a nearby alley or passage awaiting unsuspecting prey.

Rival Adventurers. Characters encounter a group of rival adventurers (see chapter 2).

Run out of Town. Characters get turned around badly, and arrive at the nearest edge of town.

Sewer Monster. An @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.jcZblJ6lqtW0ePxe]{Otyugh} feasting on offal lurks near a sewer access point.

Shadows of Drakkenheim. 5 ([[/r 2d4]]) @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.QGcQYZbVl4bWzi4E]{Shadows} slowly follow the characters. They try to remain hidden and follow the party until one of the player characters is more than ten feet away from the others, then the shadows strike in an attempt to overwhelm the straggler. An @UUID[Actor.lAt2j5PaTnH71T5O] leads these shadows when encountered in the Inner City.

Shambling Husks. 7 ([[/r 2d6]]) @UUID[Actor.9Ip2Xdb0FDnrWeEh]{Haze Husks} stumble and shuffle around the streets. In this unsettling gait, they play out scenes of their former everyday lives.

Stalking Vermin. 14 ([[/r 4d6]]) @UUID[Actor.v6osXCahFwmobuQz]{Ratlings} and 5 ([[/r 2d4]]) @UUID[Actor.yFc1bSbhRbCHjRFs]{Ratling Guttersnipes} have set up an ambush. These ratlings use bait to lure prey towards a dead-end street or sewer passage where the guttersnipes lurk on high ground to snipe their quarry with ranged attacks.

Troll Traveller. A @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.ZHAFrnCwCz17dmLc] is heading through the ruins to join the trolls at King's Gate. He wears a large pack containing raw contaminated meat, a tankard of rancid ale, 11 ([[/r 2d10]]) gold, and a few sets of tools and trinkets. If encountered near a bridge in the Inner City, there are 3 @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.ZHAFrnCwCz17dmLc]{Trolls} instead.

Uninvited Guests. The characters arrive at the nearest city gate.

Wandered into the Garden. The characters arrive at the nearest edge of Queen's Park Garden.

Watching Gargoyles. 2 ([[/r 1d4]]) @UUID[Actor.nPZV2GKXoktLDu31]{Wall Gargoyles} roaming overhead swoop down to attack. If encountered in the Inner City, there are 7 ([[/r 2d6]]) instead.

Wrong Turn. The characters find themselves back where they started an hour ago. I guess you took a wrong turn somewhere?

“Like trying to breathe on a scorching day, the air burns, eyes water. I constantly wish I was taking a bath, I feel dirty just being in it.”

— Sebastian Crowe

Delerium Hunt.name: Delerium Hunt
Delerium Hunt.text:
Delerium Hunt



“Prove to us you can survive in the ruins, andthen maybe we'll see if we can work together.”

In this short introduction to exploring Drakkenheim, player characters search the ruins for delerium and other plunder they can sell in Emberwood Village. Along the way, they'll face a few random encounters in the ruins against monsters, rival adventurers, and faction patrols.

Adventure Hook

Prospecting and Plunder. This fundamental hook is simple: the characters head into the Outer City Ruins on their own initiative to seek out whatever treasure and delerium they can find. Allow characters to take the reigns and plan their route. If for some reason characters don't think to do this on their own, a friendly NPC contact in Emberwood Village or even a faction lieutenant suggests the characters experience the ruins firsthand and prove they can survive the dangers there. It's risky, but there's a chance to make good money!

Events

Use the guidelines throughout this chapter as characters explore the ruins. Finding a delerium deposit in the Cratered Street requires characters successfully search the ruins once as described above. Check for random encounters normally, but use these events along the way:

Approaching Drakkenheim

If this is the first time the characters are venturing into Drakkenheim, read:

Nestled within a pine-covered valley, Drakkenheim is a walled metropolis that straddles the wide and sluggish Drann River. A high rocky hill rises above the city, upon which perches Castle Drakken. Below the imposing fortress, cobblestone streets weave around densely-packed stone buildings and slate-shingle spires. The city spills from the outer walls into a ruined urban sprawl.

The great dome of Saint Vitruvio's Cathedral stands prominently southwest of the castle. At the heart of the city lies the Cosmological Clocktower of Market Square, and to the northwest is the Inscrutable Tower of the Amethyst Academy. The soaring obsidian-glass building is broken in half at the middle, but the top still hovers above in defiance of gravity.

Four bridges reach across the Drann River like desperate limbs; one is covered in massive stone statues of the heroes of old, and another lurches under the weight of the ramshackle homes and other buildings constructed upon its length.

Billowing clouds of midnight purple and dusky violet mask the sky overhead, casting the city in a dismal gloom. In the rare moments where the clouds part, stray sunbeams scornfully shine upon the city. There hasn't been a clear day in Drakkenheim in fifteen years.

Entering the Ruins

The mist-shrouded countryside gives way to crumbling buildings and twisting mud-filled streets. Entering the desolate city ruins, you pass the bloated corpse of a long-dead horse. The smell of ozone fills the cold air as you walk through the tattered rubble of the Outer City. Once in a while you hear a barking dog, then perhaps a scream carried on the wind.

  • If the player characters trigger a random encounter, instead of rolling on the Outer City table, use the Ratling Scavengers or Lost Ones results.

Cratered Street

This blasted street is filled with small craters.Tiny crystals glow with prismatic light within each.

  • Characters find this location once they successfully search the ruins and score two or more successful check results.
  • There are 6 @UUID[Actor.9Ip2Xdb0FDnrWeEh]{Haze Husks} stumbling aimlessly around the craters.
  • Characters can extract 10 ([[/r 3d6]]) delerium chips worth 10 gp each and 3 ([[/r 1d6]]) delerium fragments worth 100 gp each. This takes about five to ten minutes.

Disputed Claims

A group of rival adventurers arrives on the site as the characters extract the delerium fragments.

  • They are a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.GlaCGcgIP6YjBjGc], a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.O3ABqI55Ir1du1Xa], and a @UUID[Actor.8L0mVQGiB3Tbu00H]. Tailor their identities and personalities to appropriately reflect your player characters. This opportunistic group tries to browbeat characters into giving up the claim.
  • If characters take too long deciding what to do about the haze husks, or take more than four hours to find the deposit, you may decide the rival adventurers have already claimed the first deposit (there are no haze husks present in this case). When the characters arrive, the rivals are extracting the delerium and gloat over the find. Characters who decide to move on to a second deposit encounter the haze husks as normal.
  • The rival adventurers have had some minor success so far. They have a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.ytlsBjYsZ7OBSEBs], 35 ([[/r 10d6]]) gold, 1d6 delerium chips, and their equipment.

Escaping the Ruins

Once the characters have found their prize, don't forget to check for random encounters as they leave the city! Only then may they pawn their finds in Emberwood Village.

Character Advancement

Once your characters complete their first successful Delerium Hunt, award them sufficient experience to advance them to 3rd level.

Expeditions Onward

Take note of which faction agents the player characters interacted with during their early interactions into Emberwood Village.Who did they get along with? Who did they impress? Who did they rub the wrong way? Whichever faction lieutenant(s) had a good rapport with your player characters approach them shortly after the characters return from their first successful expedition to the ruins. The faction lieutenant then offers the characters a mission to one of the locations detailed in chapter 6 - we recommend River or Ansom send characters to the Rat's Nest, and Nathaniel, Ophelia, or Blackjack Mel can send characters to the Chapel of Saint Brenna.

Beyond this point, the paths the characters might take are in their hands. Use the rumours, Adventure Hooks provided for each location, and the dossiers of the factions to navigate their choices through the Outer City, advancing to the Inner City, and eventually to Castle Drakken.

Chapter 5-Exploring Drakkenheim.name: Chapter 5-Exploring Drakkenheim
Chapter 5-Exploring Drakkenheim.text:
Chapter 5:
Exploring Drakkenheim

Following an overview of the city itself, this chapter introduces the core mechanics for running urban exploration in Drakkenheim: navigating the city streets and sewers, generating random encounters, and the properties of the mysterious Haze. You'll want to refer to these mechanics throughout the campaign, alongside the appendix sections of this book that detail the rules for Contamination, Delerium, the Random Encounter Tables, and of course, the City Map. Finally, this chapter closes with an introductory exploration adventure: a Delerium Hunt!

City Overview

Drakkenheim was a grandiose capital city famous for its many architectural wonders. The even-handed rule of House von Kessel fostered a vibrant and industrious spirit that welcomed folk throughout the realm and beyond, and the city was an international hub for trade and culture. Nearly a hundred thousand people called Drakkenheim home, and thousands more lived in small villages and hamlets a few days' travel from the city. Only a few hundred people survived the cataclysm that devastated the city, and the folk who lived in the surrounding countryside have abandoned the area for safer regions.

The recorded history of Drakkenheim stretches back about six hundred years, but a settlement and fortification have stood here since antiquity. The city was named after its founders, the now-extinct House von Drakken. Four distinct dynasties have ruled the city since, with House von Kessel claiming the throne one hundred and fifty years ago.

Drakkenheim is divided into three main regions:

  • The Outer City, estates, suburbs, and slums surrounding the city walls.
  • The Inner City, protected by the City Walls and accessible through five Gates.
  • Castle Drakken, a palace and military fortification that lies atop a high crag.

The city itself is further divided by the Drann River. Common parlance calls the two halves the North Ward and the South Ward.

Streets

Five major highways lead to Drakkenheim. The roads transition into the city's main streets: King's Road, Temple Road, Shepherd's Way, Champion's Way, and College Street. Each passes through a correspondingly-named gate, and ranges from twenty to forty feet wide with broad sidewalks along either side. Wrought-iron lamp posts and sewer drains are placed throughout. They converge at Market Square. Elsewhere in the city, the common cobblestone-paved roads are twelve to eighteen feet wide. Most have a narrow two-foot wide brick sidewalk. Sidestreets are often no more than ten feet wide, and in other areas only a narrow alley separates the buildings. In the Outer City slums, many roads are merely gravel-covered or raw dirt, though there are some stone-paved streets.

Buildings

Drakkenheim is a city of stone buildings and slate spires. Many in the Inner City may be three or four storeys tall, sometimes taller. Most are tightly packed townhouses built on stone ground levels, although the upper levels are often made from wood, and boast fine glass windows and sturdy chimneys. Wealthier homes even feature indoor plumbing directly connected to the city's water system. Dozens of smaller chapel domes and spires mark distinct boroughs in the city. In contrast, the Outer City is mostly a ramshackle slum consisting of crumbling tenements, wattle and daub cottages, and fieldstone shacks. However, the northern estates and the sections along major roads boast fine construction similar to that of the inner city.

Drann River

The Drann River is roughly four hundred feet wide and flows southwest. The water is deep, slow-moving, and thoroughly contaminated. Four stone causeways span the water. Stone quays and piers surround the river within the Inner City.

Contaminated Water. All water in Drakkenheim is contaminated, including the Drann River. Characters who end their turn in contaminated water must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or gain one level of contamination.

City Walls

Stone masonry walls forty feet high and five to ten feet thick separate the Inner City and the Outer City, with entrance via five gates. These fortifications present a major obstacle when exploring the city: the five city gates are occupied by faction forces or monsters, and hostile gargoyles attack any who scale the walls. Refer to the “Walls of Drakkenheim” in Chapter 7: Inside the Walls of Drakkenheim for details.

Castle Drakken

Atop a high cliff on the north side of town perches Castle Drakken. The fortification and palace is described in chapter 9.

The Haze.name: The Haze
The Haze.text:
The Haze is magical radiation emitted by the vast concentration of delerium in Drakkenheim. It permeates the ruins and extends about two miles outside the walls.

Effects on Characters

Creatures do not gain any benefits from finishing a long rest within the Haze.

Creatures may remain in the Haze for up to twenty-four hours before they must finish a long rest to recuperate from exposure to its eldritch energies. For each additional hour spent within the Haze beyond twenty four hours, a creature must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or gain one level of contamination.

Most monsters encountered in Drakkenheim possess the fully contaminated trait (see Appendix A) and ignore these effects.

Environmental Effects

At dawn, the Haze magically manifests mist throughout the ruins. Characters can see normally through the mist up to 150 feet. Vision beyond is lightly obscured, but vision past 300 feet is totally obscured. Any mists dispersed during the day reform ten minutes later.

The mists dampen sunlight. Creatures with sunlight sensitivity or similar traits do not suffer these penalties during the day while within the Haze.

The mist disperses shortly after sunset, but the Haze appears as a shifting corona of octarine light shimmering over the city during the night. Floating motes and hazy particles hang over the city streets providing illumination akin to moonlight, and delerium crystals emit a bright glow to a range of five feet.

The corpses of beasts and humanoid creatures do not rot within the Haze. However, most unattended corpses left in the streets are devoured within a day by ravenous ratlings. Other food and drink spoils after 2d6 days within the Haze.

Effects on Spells

The erratic magic of the Haze disrupts many spells cast within it. Any teleportation spell cast by a creature outside the Haze targeting a creature or location within the Haze automatically fails and the spell slot is wasted. Creatures inside the Haze may teleport normally within, but any attempt to leave the Haze via teleportation fails. Telepathic communications or effects such as the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.GtGjNjPBgUHxGYAD] spell transmitted from outside the Haze fail to contact a character within it, and vice-versa. Sensors created by divination spells can't appear inside the Haze, and those created outside the Haze can't enter it. Finally, other divination spells fail to reveal useful information about delerium, the Haze, the origins of the meteor, or any events that occurred within the Haze.

When a character attempts any of the above using a spell or other effect, they must succeed on a DC 15 Intelligence saving throw. On a failure, they take 6d6 psychic damage and become incapacitated with madness until they finish a long rest. During this time they speak only in gibberish. A @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.WzvJ7G3cqvIubsLk] spell ends this effect.

@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.ap4dmtshjEbwU3Ts], @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.NXWWWgHtWb7Nv21F], and similar spells or abilities do not provide shelter or protection from the Haze. However, characters may rest within a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.pn4SnsFDvYDiE6rC] spell cast within the Haze.

Deep Haze

Certain areas are so suffused by the Haze that mere exposure is extremely dangerous and potentially fatal. Known as the Deep Haze, these areas have the following additional traits:

  • Deep Haze is instantly recognized by a thick prismatic fog. Characters can see normally through this fog up to 60 feet. Vision beyond is lightly obscured, but vision past 120 feet is totally obscured. If dispersed during the day, the fog reforms one minute later.
  • Characters entering the Deep Haze must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw, and again for each full hour spent within. On a failed saving throw, they suffer 10 ([[/r 3d6]]) necrotic damage and gain one level of contamination.

The Haze map at the back of this book indicates which areas of the city are covered by the Deep Haze. Other locations suffused by the Deep Haze are noted in location descriptions.

Delerium Sludge

Gargantuan delerium geodes perspire an opalescent sludge. Characters submerged in delerium sludge make a DC 18 Constitution saving throw at the start of their turn. They take 42 ([[/r 12d6]]) necrotic damage on a failed saving throw, and half as much on a successful one. In addition, characters who fail the saving throw gain one level of contamination.

Navigating the Ruins.name: Navigating the Ruins
Navigating the Ruins.text:
Drakkenheim behaves more like a dangerous wilderness than an urban location. Characters risk perilous random encounters with hostile monsters and mysterious magical phenomena as they traverse the ruins, but may also stumble upon delerium, lost treasures, and faction agents.

Getting to the City

Aside from Emberwood Village, all towns and villages within one week's travel of Drakkenheim have been wholly abandoned. The nearest large cities are a three-week journey away.

Travel times from safe havens are indicated below. When travelling to the city, characters may arrive anywhere on the city outskirts.

Origin Point Distance Travel Time on Foot
Eckerman Mill 1 mile 20 minutes
Camp Dawn 2 miles 1 hour
Emberwood Village 5 miles 2 hours

Urban Exploration

As the player characters traverse the ruined city, you can handle urban exploration in an abstract manner as follows:

  • Using the city map, identify approximately where the characters are currently located.
  • Let the players determine what direction they want to go and choose their travel pace (see “Moving Through the Streets” below).
  • Check for random encounters each hour (see below, consult Chapter 5 for tables).

It's not necessary to precisely track which streets the characters take; a rough route is sufficient. Correspondingly, navigation checks are not required. Characters can locate key adventure sites without much difficulty, as long as they have approximate directions and a general description of their destination. Instead, the random encounter tables include several situations in which the characters might make a wrong turn or become lost.

Moving through the Streets

Ruined buildings and maze-like streets are exceptionally difficult terrain. How fast characters can move on foot depends on their priority:

  • Fast. At this pace, characters advance one mile per hour. They take the most direct route to their destination and move openly on major streets. Characters cannot use stealth, and make Perception checks with disadvantage. When checking for random encounters (see “Random Encounters” later in this chapter), each character rolls twice and takes the lower result.
  • Normal. At this pace, characters advance one-half mile per hour. They proceed carefully through the ruins staying vigilant for threats and landmarks. Characters cannot use stealth, but may make Investigation and Perception checks with advantage.
  • Slow. At this pace, characters advance one-quarter mile per hour to evade hostile threats. They sneak down back alleys and avoid major streets. Characters may use stealth, and make Perception checks normally.

Searching the Ruins

Use these guidelines whenever the characters deliberately search for something in the ruins, such as scavenged supplies, lost treasures, unknown locations, a hidden foe, or a safe place to rest. Conducting a good search takes at least one hour; during which the characters may survey an area with up to a ¼ mile diameter. After one hour of searching, each character makes an Investigation or Wisdom (Survival) check (DC 10 for the Outer City, DC 15 for the Inner City). Exceeding the DC by 5 or more grants an additional success. Whether or not the characters find anything is determined by the total number of successes:

  • 3 or more successes. The party finds what they are looking for if it can be found within the search area, otherwise, they conclusively rule out any possibility that what they were seeking was in the area of their search.
  • 2 or more failed checks. The characters stumble into a Random Encounter, but if they still had enough successes, they also find whatever they sought.

If your party is larger or smaller than four characters, increase or decrease the number of required successes proportionately. Alternatively, characters might use special skills when searching for something specific:

  • Arcana. Delerium deposits or magical phenomena.
  • Cartographer's Tools. Searching an area the characters have visited at least once before themselves, or for which they have a map.
  • History. Specific and notable monuments, buildings,or residences.
  • Nature. Exploring natural environments such as Queen's Park.
  • Survival. Tracking monsters or people.
  • Stealth and Perception checks do not contribute to successes, but may be used to evade or detect hostile threats while the characters search the ruins.

Drakkenheim City Streets

Scale 1sq = 5ft.

Drakkenheim Sewers

Scale 1sq = 5ft.

Finding Delerium Deposits

When characters seek out delerium by Searching the Ruins (described above), success requires a sucessful Intelligence (Arcana or Investigation) or Wisdom (Survival) check with a DC indicated by the table below. A check result which exceeds the DC by 5 or more grants an additional success.

Outer City Delerium Deposits (DC 15)

2 success or fewer Nothing
3 successes 10 ([[/r 3d6]]) delerium chips worth 10 gp each
4 success 3 ([[/r 1d6]]) delerium fragments worth 100 gold each
5 or more successes 1 delerium shard worth 500 gp

Inner City Delerium Deposits (DC 20)

1 success or fewer Nothing
2 successes 10 ([[/r 3d6]]) delerium chips worth 10 gp each
3 successes 7 ([[/r 2d6]]) delerium fragments worth 100 gold each
4 successes 3 ([[/r 1d6]]) delerium shards worth 500 gp
5 or more successes 1 delerium crystal worth 1,000 gp

Results are cumulative, so a group that makes four successes finds 3d6 delerium chips and 1d6 fragments. As normal, generate a random encounter if characters have two or more failed check results while searching for delerium.

Characters searching within a quarter mile of the Crater's Edge receive one automatic additional success due to the rich quantities of delerium found in this exceptionally dangerous region.

Drakkenheim Sewers

The Drakkenheim sewers were a sophisticated engineering marvel. The system combined underground gravity-based aqueducts and drainage canals with carefully placed locks and floodgates to deliver clean and fresh water to the city population and draw away the massive quantities of sewage and wastewater. Major canals run under the city streets, and can be accessed from the surface by numerous maintenance hatches.

After over a decade of disuse, most tunnels are flooded with contaminated water and many other passages have collapsed. Other sections are now monster lairs. As a result, travelling in the sewers is extraordinarily hazardous and ill-advised. However, characters might consider taking the sewers to locate a route under the city walls, or to gain access to hidden underground dungeons such as the cistern (see chapter 7) or the Court of Thieves (see chapter 8).

Sewer Navigation. Handle sewer navigation abstractly using the same mechanics for navigating the streets above, except characters move at half their normal pace through the twisting tunnels. Sewer passages and access points could be almost anywhere in the city, so use the surface map as an approximate guide to track the character's progress. In addition, after each hour spent in the sewers characters must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or gain one level of contamination from contact with sewer water.

Searching the Sewers. Just as characters may search the streets, they might search the sewers for hidden entrances to some adventure sites. Other secret locations may be found in this manner. A DC 20 check result is needed for success when searching the sewer passages.

Other Exploration Activities

Taking a Rest. Before taking a short rest in the ruins, characters may spend one hour locating a safe spot or hiding their campsite. If they do, don't check for random encounters during their rest. Note that the Haze (described above) prevents characters from benefiting from a long rest in the city. Characters who attempt to do so anyways check for random encounters each hour.

Flying. Flying characters may soar across the city rapidly. At your discretion, they may risk hostile attention from the gargoyles defending the walls or the harpies inhabiting the Inner City.

Vehicles. Land vehicles are largely impractical in the ruins, although characters could use a boat to travel via the river normally (though at your discretion characters may risk attack from aquatic or sewer-dwelling monsters!) Characters moving with a land vehicle or portaging a water vehicle travel ¼ mile per hour. Land and water vehicles can't be hidden without magic, but individual characters might be able to use stealth.

Finding Sustenance. Finding suitable sustenance within Drakkenheim is difficult since most food and water within the city is either spoiled or contaminated. Instead, characters should bring their own supply of food and water from outside the city. Nevertheless, a character who eats or drinks anything found in Drakkenheim that has not been magically purified makes a DC 15 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, they gain one level of contamination.

A Combined Approach

Drakkenheim is dangerous and unpredictable. There is no such thing as a foolproof plan for safely exploring the ruins. Nevertheless, characters using special resources, spells, magic items, or with a very inventive plan might greatly improve their navigation. For example, characters could use spells such as @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.1N8dDMMgZ1h1YJ3B] and @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.pRMvmknwLf2tdMTj] together to travel quickly while remaining unseen, or perhaps @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.YBda6nLKjxdT1LbS] helps characters move over the river. If they aren't expending resources, you should call for a few difficult skill checks. On a failure, they stumble into a difficult random encounter with extra complications.

Escaping the Ruins

Characters must use their resources carefully while exploring Drakkenheim, as there is always a chance they'll face a random encounter or two when leaving the ruins as well. At some point during their adventures, characters might be heavily wounded and out of resources deep in the city ruins. As they stagger back to Emberwood Village, they roll up a difficult random encounter. This could be the one that ends it for them! Be lenient the first time this happens, but merciless the second.

Chapter 6 - Outside the Walls.name: 第六章：探索德拉肯海姆外城

Chapter 6-Outside the Walls.name: 德拉肯海姆外城
Chapter 6-Outside the Walls.text:
第六章: 城墙之外

各式的寻宝者通过在外城探险而发家致富，或是横遭不幸。这些断壁残垣环绕着城墙，就像绝望地寻求庇护的人群。请按下文描述外城废墟带给人的破败感：

沿着德拉肯海姆破败的大道前行着，你经过了几座完全坍塌成废墟的建筑。那些仍矗立着的建筑也不过是在崩溃边缘徘徊的可怜虫罢了。有极少数的建筑虽未受损，但仍有明显的被废弃和破坏的痕迹：破碎的窗户、斑驳的油漆、腐朽的门铰链、受潮下垂的屋顶。龟裂的鹅卵石路上堆满了被遗弃的垃圾、破旧马车，偶尔还有残留的血迹或散落的骸骨。街道上弥漫着薄雾，时不时还会有细微的奇异光芒闪过。而现在，街道上冷冷清清，如死一般的寂静。

“魔法一直都象征着欢乐和游戏，直到有人被它随机地变成了一株盆栽……其实那也挺有趣的。”

— 维奥·斯耶纳

总览

外城的一些地标是前期探索德拉肯海姆的理想地点。不过，等级未到 3 级的角色可能会觉得这些地点也相当具有挑战性。冒险者小队并不一定要造访这里介绍的每一个地点，但那些完全探索了这些地点的角色可以升至 6 级。角色们可以按照任意顺序造访这些地点，但“鼠窝”和“圣布伦娜小教堂”是理想的起始地点。

冒险引子：本节中的每个地点都提供了冒险引子，你可以使用这些引子来引导角色们探索该地点：大多数引子都将涉及一名会和冒险者小队接触的派系副官。请参阅第四章：烬木村中的接触各派系，以了解各派系的副官以及他们在村中的位置。

城墙和城门： 在进入内城之前，小队应当先探索外城。不过，如果角色们决心希望进入内城，他们当然可以这么尝试！如果小队接近了任意一座城门或试图攀越城墙，请参考第七章：德拉肯海姆城墙之内。

一旦角色们通过探索废墟获得了一定的经验，并与一个或多个派系建立了联系，他们就可以着手对付德拉肯海姆的城墙，然后开始探索内城的各个地点了（详见第七章）。

Chapel of Saint Brenna.name: 圣布伦娜小教堂
Chapel of Saint Brenna.text:
圣布伦娜小教堂

德拉肯海姆许多街区的中心都建有侍奉神圣之火的小教堂。这些教堂是举办宗教礼拜、婚礼、社区聚会和葬礼的场所，又因为每个教堂之下都建有一个小型墓穴，这里也是普通人安葬死者、火化遗骸的地方。不过，其中的许多墓室也是神圣之火的牧师和圣武士的木乃伊化遗体的安息之地，有些墓室中甚至还存放着圣物。圣布伦娜小教堂保存着一件特别珍贵的圣物，它的下落也是直到最近才被人知晓：@UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-core.items.Item.SceT000000000024]{圣维特鲁维奥节杖}。现在有三个派系正在寻找这件圣物：天火信众、白银骑士团和女王的弟兄们。

总览

在这场冒险中，角色们会调查圣布伦娜小教堂下的墓穴地牢，并找回圣维特鲁维奥节杖。棘手的问题是，至少还有两个其他派系也派出了自己的突击队来夺取节杖。如果你真的想要给予角色们一点挑战，你还可以加入第三个派系！在角色们抵达时，其中一个派系的小队已经在搜索小教堂的上层区域了，而另一个竞争派系的队伍也会在稍后抵达这里并加入争夺的行列。角色们需要决定该如何应对这两批其他派系的特工：他们可以和他们对抗，设计诱骗他们，潜行躲过他们，或者和他们通过某种方式交涉。

墓穴中的谜团需要角色们发挥创造力来想出一些非常规的创新解决方案来应对，因为本就不存在所谓"正确"的解决方法。但是，如果角色们在途中惊醒了那些被埋葬的牧师和圣武士的遗体，他们就会碰到一个有趣的新麻烦，因为这些不死生物在被摧毁后还会重新复活，除非他们能通过适当的方法再次安息。

冒险引子

圣维特鲁维奥节杖。 最近，一群对手冒险者在另一处废墟中找到了许多的信件和公文，其中提到圣维特鲁维奥节杖就被埋在圣布伦娜小教堂的地下。不幸的是，这些冒险者在对于如何利用这些信息上出现了意见分歧，于是他们分道扬镳。他们各自带回的消息引起了各派系的注意。现在，率先寻回节杖的比赛开始了！虽然每个派系都派了一支突击队前往了小教堂，但只有和冒险者小队走的最近的那个派系才会来寻求角色们的帮助。

其中一个派系的信使在烬木村找到了角色们，他急切地要求他们去和以下派系的副官之一见面：

  • 位于圣阿登纳小教堂的圣火守护者@UUID[Actor.1IaDUyBM9G4EEphL]{奥菲利亚·苇叶}
  • 位于亨德里克斯农场的@UUID[Actor.fKwswI79J2z7lM0i]{那萨利尔·燧石}
  • 位于骷髅与剑酒馆的@UUID[Actor.btuo8mywkRo5g6M9]{"黑杰克"梅尔}

副官会直接切入正题。

  • 角色们需要立刻行动，因为其他派系已经派出了自己的特工们。

  • 奥菲利亚·苇叶。"我们不能允许圣维特鲁维奥节杖落入那群盗贼或者邪教徒之手。帮我们找回它，等你们回到黎明营地见到我时，我会让你的努力得到丰厚的回报。"

  • 那萨利尔·燧石。"我们不关心金银财宝这些世俗之物的价值，但如果你们能帮助我们完成这个任务，你们就将会是我们信仰的捍卫者。你们必须把权杖带给卢克雷蒂亚·马西亚斯本人，她就在圣赛莉娜修道院的神圣厅堂里。她会给予你们一份丰厚的恩赐。"

  • "黑杰克"梅尔。"对于合适的买家来说，那个节杖可是价值可期……但如果你没有对的路子，靠你自己是不可能把它卖出去的。你会得到一份分成，不过我们要是从哪听说你打算自己卖掉这玩意，跟我们玩双重交易的把戏，那你可得小心吃不了兜着走。"

互动

没有和角色合作的派系都会派遣自己的突击队前往圣布伦娜小教堂。白银骑士团的突击队永远会最先抵达，而天火信众会在角色们刚好带着节杖离开小教堂时抵达。女王的弟兄们既可以率先到达（如果角色们为白银骑士团工作），也可以在角色们短休时现身（如果角色们为天火信众工作）。

天火信众。 人类@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.tYfQIxCJT0WaaKmc]{邪教狂信者}卡嘉·布劳恩带领着 8 个人类@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.qkLNA1lKMMJpxuWg]{邪教徒}。她是一个苗条的中年女性，而且坚信自己的所作所为是正义的。

白银骑士团。人类@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.D5UqYD1EnTrJaMTO]{骑士}布莱斯·兰德里爵士带领着 4 名@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.E9CvDPDg5dFEpVjS]{警卫}。这群笨拙又瘦长的战士们坚持履行"正确"之事，他们拒绝以任何方式损坏教堂或亵渎墓穴。他们每人都有一匹@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.T1xZTDCGuvMBSq8d]{战马}被拴在小教堂外的树边。

女王的弟兄们。 人类@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.rb7OJt822wIO52qY]{强盗首领}罗什全身布满严重的烧伤痕迹，他带领着 8 个人类@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.n4TEv7inVUkyZviN]{强盗}。他们将从这份工作中得到每人 1000GP 的报酬，但他们还想找找能不能有更优厚的东家。

关于如何扮演这些派系的突击队，请参考派系档案中的扮演特点部分，有关其战斗策略的详情，请参考突击队部分。

区域详述

教堂所处地

在一个荒凉的住宅区中央，一座破败的小教堂矗立于一个小山丘上。尽管已经损毁严重，其石板圆顶仍高出周围的联排别墅稍许。小教堂拱形双开门的入口两侧有两个圆柱形的塔楼。其中一座塔楼已经完全坍塌，变成了一个约 15 尺高的碎石堆，它留下了一个巨大的缺口，可以直接通往小教堂的一层。另一座只剩两层高的塔楼则仍屹立在地面上。在塔基的周围堆满了瓦砾和石块。小教堂优雅的拱形窗户上镶满了彩色的马赛克玻璃，它曾经装饰着这座小教堂，但如今大部分的窗户都已破碎不堪。

[1] 火葬花园

小教堂的后面有一个小露台，露台上设有石凳和日晷，还有一条小径将小教堂与东面一个带围墙的花园与之连接起来。园内的两块土地曾是葬礼用的火葬场。一尊身着板甲的忧郁女性雕像双手将一根银制权杖紧握在胸前，她是这片火葬场的守望者。

  • 雕像后的一扇金属活板门被一把挂锁锁上了。挂锁的钥匙早已遗失，但锁仍可以被一个 DC 20 力量或敏捷检定撬开或摧毁。如果门被打开，其下的陡峭阶梯就会把你带往地下的火葬通道（区域 6）。
  • DC10 宗教。这座雕像描绘的是圣塔尔娜，神圣之火信仰的创立者。
  • DC10 历史或宗教。神圣之火的信仰要求他们火化死者，并将他们的骨灰埋葬于教堂的墓穴中。
  • 雕像的手中握着一根银质的@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.eQNXan0zp279jDtk]{不动权杖}。它直径 1 英寸，长 15 英寸。权杖上的按钮是激活状态中的。如果再次使用按钮关闭激活，权杖就会从雕像手中滑出。权杖除了底部的边缘有一个楔形的凹痕外，杆身非常光滑。这根权杖的作用是作为绞盘室（区域 4）的把手使用。
  • 如果女王的弟兄们突击队率先抵达，他们会出现在这里。他们把火葬花园中的不动权杖误以为是真正的圣维特鲁维奥节杖。他们（错误地）推测如果按下权杖的按钮将会触发某种机关。因此，他们正在研究该怎么取下权杖，而且没想出什么答案来，因为这里真的没有任何机关。

[2] 小教堂

双开门吱呀地打开了，映入眼帘的是一条铺着地毯、装饰着烛台的短走廊。走廊直接通向小教堂内的圣殿。塔顶坍塌后形成的坑洼中积满了咸涩的雨水。

小教堂的中心是一座三层的石制祭坛，祭坛上有一个巨大的铜质火盆。里面装着已经石质化的木头和灰。祭坛的旁边还有几张祈祷者长凳和一个小祭坛盒。神圣之火的崇拜者曾经聚集在这里，手拉手围着火盆顶礼膜拜。

污垢、灰尘和碎屑覆盖在大部分的地板上，马赛克地面上已经风干碎裂的油漆也随处可见。窗户之间的墙壁上绘有关于神圣之火的圣徒和烈士的褪色壁画。三个凹室内各有一尊已受到时间和风霜严重侵蚀的大型雕像。其中，北面的凹室里雕刻的是传说中的圣塔尔娜，她面对着一个有着长长的触手的巨大双头恶魔而不为所动。东侧凹室的雕像是德拉肯海姆的主保圣人，圣维特鲁维奥。西面的雕像是圣布伦娜，这座小教堂也因她而得名。而她正在施展复活的奇迹。

房间里散落着被毁坏的文件、铁质火盆和青铜灯具，其中有一些还挂在屋顶的木梁上。房间里散发着一股沥青的气味。

  • 搜索火盆的底下可以找出两瓶@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.FvNOwWbh5FXyX4xe]{炽火胶}。
  • 这里的书籍和纸张都是神圣之火的教典和赞美诗的副本，其中并没有什么特别的知识或信息。
  • 祭坛盒中有一个价值 25GP 的银质大口水壶， @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.8dzaICjGy6mTUaUr]{祝福术}和 @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.nqBDWkVOfcGZt4YU]{妖火}的法术卷轴，两张 @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.MK6gpQMeDFo0cP9f]{不灭明焰}法术卷轴，一个神圣之火的银质圣徽，三小瓶圣油（视作圣水），和一块香。
  • 后门的铰链已经腐烂，除非小心翼翼地打开它，否则后门就会哗啦一声倒塌在地。
  • 水坑正缓慢地通过地板缝隙向下渗水。
  • 圣塔尔娜的雕像上刻有"圣塔尔娜手持银色的真理，为圣火的治愈之光开启道路"的字样。这指的是火葬花园外的雕像手持的那根@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.eQNXan0zp279jDtk]{不动权杖}。

一条石制螺旋楼梯通向小教堂的地下室。楼梯的一半处有一扇铁栅栏门拦住了去路。铁门上有一把锁。

  • 铁门的钥匙丢失了。但是，铁门可以被一次 DC 20 的力量检定破坏，或者也可以花 1 分钟通过一次DC 15 的敏捷（盗贼工具）检定把门锁撬开。
  • 如果悄悄走下楼梯，就能听到微弱的火焰噼啪声和尘土飞旋的声音，偶尔还能听到原初语的叫喊声、咯咯声或咕哝声。这些声音是居住在地下室的魔蝠发出的。
  • 如果白银骑士团的突击队率先抵达，他们会出现在这里。他们把马匹拴在了外面的一棵树边，留下一个@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.E9CvDPDg5dFEpVjS]{警卫}看管它们。兰德里爵士和其他的人则进入探索这片区域。他们把武器放在了门边，正在寻找可以打开地下室的门的钥匙。不幸的是，他们没有意识到钥匙早就不见了，他们会花费好几个钟头进行毫无意义的搜索，因为他们拒绝因破坏铁门而"亵渎"这座教堂。

[3] 地下墓室

小教堂的下面是一个地下墓室。这里的墙壁上凿出了数百个壁龛，里面存放着骨灰瓮、陶罐和彩绘花瓶。墓室中央三根柱子上的小壁龛里放着人的头骨，半融化的蜡烛像皇冠一样放在这些头骨上。拱形的天花板高 10 尺，几根支柱支撑着小教堂的地基。铁制的吊灯和青铜烛台遍布各处，这里的许多蜡烛仍在燃烧，它们散发出紫色、绿色还有第八虹色的火焰。一阵诡异的风从奇怪的位置吹来，激起了墓室中细小的尘埃，让烛光变得飘忽不定。其中两个凹室里有两扇坚固的橡木门，门上嵌有铁制的网格，它们都通向东面。水则从墓室南端天花板上的裂缝中漏了下来。

  • 骨灰瓮里、在亚麻布的包裹里、或是小盒子里都装着骨灰、骨头碎片，有时还有一些头骨，然后它们被安葬在了这个地下墓室的壁龛里。骨灰盒上都刻有死者的名字。
  • 水渗入了地面裂缝的土壤之中。

小灰，小尘，小烟和小烬

"在那别动，肉包子！你们这是非法入侵！你们最好给咱带了点什么好东西，大肉块！"

这个地下墓室现在是几只魔蝠的巢穴，其中有两只@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.UthHOT7QfZfEIUue]{蒸汽魔蝠}，一只@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.BUCfQ7ihaXX75Vai]{尘魔蝠}，和一只 @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.oJCOB9X2BPsBkWW5]{熔岩魔蝠}。十五年前，紫晶学院曾派遣这些魔蝠来对废墟进行侦查，但他们放弃了任务，并把这个地下墓室当成了自己的新家。

它们非常喜欢这里的环境，因为这里充满了与它们自身构成相似的材料和元素。他们的"家"不容任何人闯入，除非有人送他们一份合适的礼物：一颗宝石。它们对外面的世界知之甚少，却喜欢对人类的"肉块"施以任性而残忍的对待。但是，他们会害怕任何穿着紫晶学院服饰的人，它们会开始痛哭流涕，并请求对方的原谅。

[4A 和 4B] 绞盘室

在这个圆形小房间的中心，有一根三尺高、一尺粗的坚固金属柱。在圆柱最顶端边缘下方，有一个直径一英寸、深约四英寸的圆柱形凹槽。

  • 这些柱子是连接下面各层墓室大门的绞盘。绞盘 A 可以打开标有字母"A"的墓门。转动绞盘 B 则可以打开标有"B"的墓门。
  • 遗憾的是，绞盘上没有把手，因此转动绞盘打开墓门变得异常困难。
  • 外面火葬花园里的雕像手持的那根@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.eQNXan0zp279jDtk]{不动权杖}就是绞盘的把手。
  • 在绞盘上安装把手后，角色就可以以一个动作转动绞盘，打开墓门。配重系统会在角色松手的一个回合之后关闭墓门，除非绞盘被固定在当前的位置（需要一个动作）或者上面的@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.eQNXan0zp279jDtk]{不动权杖}被激活。
  • 如果找不到原本的把手，也可以制作一个替代品。木杆每使用一轮就有百分之五十的几率断裂，而金属杆则可以完美地正常使用（但需要固定到位）。
  • 使用了合适工具的角色只需花费一小时的时间，并通过一次 DC 15 的智力检定，就能制作出一个用于固定绞盘的塞子或装置。
  • 即使没有把手，绞盘仍可以被抬起。角色可以使用一个动作，并成功通过一次 DC 20 的力量检定，这样也能将墓门升高到足以让一个人从下面爬过去的程度。此后的每一轮他都必须重复该检定来维持这扇门的开启状态。
  • 一旦松开绞盘，门就会轰然关闭，并对门下的人造成 3d6 点钝击伤害。使用绞盘安全地关上墓门需要一个动作。
  • 墓门一旦完全升起就可以一直处于被打开的状态。这需要花费一个动作，并且那个人每轮都需要进行 DC 23 的力量检定。
  • 角色可以用一个合适且足够坚固的物体来撑住门，但墓门很重，可能会直接压断支撑物。每轮掷一个骰子，使用更大的骰子来表示更坚固的物体（脆弱物体的骰子为 1d4，坚固物体的骰子为 1d12，等等）。如果掷出 1，支撑物就会断裂或被折断，门就会猛地关上。

由于两个绞盘只有一个把手，因此要进入圣物室（区域 10）通常需要用一个绞盘打开一组门，这时墓门会开始缓缓关闭，然后立刻将把手移到另一个绞盘上，再打开另一组门，然后重复上述过程才行。这就意味着所有人要么分头行动，要么就得想办法同时打开所有的墓门。

玩家们可能会猜想也许第二根不动权杖被遗失在了某处，并可能会花一些时间来寻找它。其实这里的设计是有意为之的，但如果你担心你的玩家可能会过于倔强地执着于寻找第二根长杖，那你也可以在区域 9 的木乃伊的手中塞一根。

[5] 涤尘喷泉

这个圆形的房间里有一个圆形石盆，里面盛着新鲜的圣水。水盆边缘的铭文写着："愿神圣之火守望着我们敬爱的逝者的灵魂"。这间密室长长的弧形墙壁被分隔成五大板块，每个板块上都绘有壁画。壁画整体展现的是三位圣火守护者正在为一位死去的圣武士举行葬礼的图景。

  • 第一幅壁画是尸体的打理过程：一名祭司清洗尸体，另一名祭司用亚麻布包裹好尸体，最后一名祭司收好圣武士的武器、盾牌和头盔。
  • 第二幅壁画中，两名祭司将尸体放在了墓板上，第三名祭司则将圣物放于尸体的手中，并在尸体的两只眼皮上各放了一颗宝石。
  • 在第三幅壁画中，祭司们在用圣水或圣油涂抹尸体。
  • 在第四幅壁画中，祭司将蜡烛放在尸体周围并点燃。
  • 最后一幅壁画表现的是一位祭司正站在尸体旁阅读一张卷轴，而其他祭司则手拉手吟诵着赞美诗。

对面的弧形矮墙上有几个破旧的架子和凹槽，里面摆满了小瓶、工具、布满灰尘的卷轴和薄薄的亚麻布。

  • 架子上有一些用于打理尸体的装备和工具，有 6 小瓶圣油，还有@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.F0GsG0SJzsIOacwV]{次级复原术}，@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.15Fa6q1nH27XfbR8]{解除魔法}和 @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.XZhdgVK3cLoxNCQl]{移除诅咒}的卷轴各一个。
  • 在瓶瓶罐罐中，可以找到 2 瓶 @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.ytlsBjYsZ7OBSEBs]{治疗药水}。
  • 圣洗池内总计可以收集 2d6 瓶圣水。
  • DC 12 历史或宗教。神圣之火的教义将牧师和圣武士的遗体视为圣物。他们相信，这些虔诚的灵魂有一天可能会再次需要他们在尘世的躯体，因此他们的遗体会被保存或制成木乃伊，而非火化。这些壁画就描绘了这一过程。


[6] 火葬场入口

叶片、青草、泥土和杂物填满了这个石室的地面。

  • 这里的楼梯通向上面的火葬场。这条通道已经很久没有人走过了。
  • 坚硬的橡木大门被卡住了，但可以通过一个动作推开。

[7] 北部墓室

这间墓室的石门没有明显的把手或铰链。门上雕刻着天使和圣贤的图案。墓门上的碑文写道："慈悲和节制支撑着光明，贪婪和仇恨裹挟来黑暗。"

  • 这个墓室的石门可以被区域 4b 的绞盘打开。

墓室门后是一个拱顶的环形大厅。墓室内被数十根蜡烛照亮，这些蜡烛被放置在墙边半圆形凹槽中的六口石棺上。每口石棺上都安放着神圣之火牧师和圣武士的遗体。破烂的布条覆盖着他们的骸骨，丝绸的缎带遮住了他们的眼睛。大多数遗体都双手交叉地放在身上，其中一手拿着火把，另一手握着烛台，但有一具遗体手上则放着盾牌，另一具遗体手上放着头盔，还有一具遗体的手上放着一把刻有天界语符文、闪烁着柔和蓝光的巨剑。

  • 每具遗体都是一个静静地躺在那里的@UUID[Actor.pmT3Kvi2pC7M5Eg0]{骷髅}。几十年前，为他们举行的最后的遗体仪式抑制住了污霭带来的复苏他们的魔法。除非他们的遗体或遗物受到侵扰，否则他们不会苏醒，不然，附近的蜡烛会突然熄灭，然后他们会起身攻击盗墓者。

  • 这些骷髅拥有以下的额外特质：
    —— 再生。如果骷髅被摧毁，它将在十分钟内恢复所有的生命值，除非将它的遗骸放置于石板上，然后在周围点上蜡烛，洒上圣水，再对着它进行一次简短的祈祷，或者对它的遗骸施放一次 @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.n4JDcFKe5ikzYmAc]{遗体防腐}或@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.XZhdgVK3cLoxNCQl]{移除诅咒}。

  • 宝藏。每具骷髅的眼窝里都镶嵌着宝石：两颗黄水晶，每颗价值 50GP。他们还紧握着一个金制或银制的神圣之火圣徽，价值 25GP。最后，这里的这把魔法巨剑名为暮光。这是一把+1 巨剑，并持续对周围 15 尺范围内发出微光照明。挥舞这把剑的生物可以说和听懂天界语。这里的其他的武器或盔甲都已破旧不堪，毫无价值。
  • DC 15 奥秘或宗教。污霭经常会使尸体自动复活。但在这些遗体上举行过的神圣仪式可以防止这种情况发生。
  • 如果这扇门最近被打开过，然后又关上了，那么角色可以通过一次 DC 15 的调查检定发现最近被扰动的灰尘和磨损石块的痕迹。由于灰尘在重新汇聚，所以这扇门一定是最近才被打开然后又关上的。

南边还有一扇石门，上面镌刻着雄伟的龙形图案，上书："当我们用信仰点燃火焰，将不再有永恒的黑暗。"

这扇门通往隐藏圣物室（区域 10）。这里可以通过区域 4a 的绞盘打开。

[8] 南部墓室

石阶通往了一个布满蜘蛛网的古老墓室，墓室的样子跟一条粗糙凿出的石道差不多。起伏不平的天花板有 10 尺高。

  • 和北部墓室（区域 7）一样，这间墓室内也有五口石棺，上面放有神圣之火牧师和圣武士的遗体。相关说明请参见上文。
  • 宝藏。每具骷髅的眼窝里都镶嵌着宝石：两颗黄水晶，每颗价值 50GP。他们还紧握着一个金制或银制的神圣之火圣徽，价值 25GP。与北面的墓室不同，这里没有留下任何魔法武器。

在通道的尽头是一扇石门，它通往圣布伦娜之墓（区域 9）。

[9] 圣布伦娜之墓

这扇厚重的石门上画有一位身着飘垂的长袍、面容安详的圣火守护者。门下刻着："圣布伦娜，愿你被永恒的光明环绕。安息吧，愿神圣之火与你同在"。

  • 这个墓室的石门可以通过区域 4b 的绞盘打开。

在这个墓室里有一块石板，周围点满了蜡烛。石板上面安放着圣布伦娜已经制成木乃伊的遗体。然而，从上方漏下来的水把周围的火光浇灭了。尽管如此，密室中仍有几盏立式的烛台，在其周围还摆放着一些陶罐和玻璃瓶。

  • 圣布伦娜保存完好的遗体躺在房间中央的石棺上。从上方天花板的损坏处渗出的水熄灭了圣布伦娜周围的蜡烛，将她作为一具@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.t8WYD7ak07X7xpx8]{木乃伊}唤醒了。由于她的身体被水浸没，因此她不像其他木乃伊那样对火焰伤害具有易伤。她具有以下附加特性：
    —— 再生。如果木乃伊被摧毁，它将在十分钟内恢复所有的生命值，除非将它的遗骸放置于石板上，然后在周围点上蜡烛，洒上圣水，再对着它进行一次简短的祈祷，或者对它的遗骸施放一次@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.XZhdgVK3cLoxNCQl]{移除诅咒 }。

  • 如果墓室的门被打开，圣布伦娜就会站起来，开始在墓穴中游荡，她会一边低语，一边胡乱地引用着圣典的内容。她已被疯狂和绝望所笼罩，并会对任何生物发起攻击。如果她经过其他的遗体附近，她会花费一个动作来唤醒它们跟随她。她不会离开地下室。

在墓室北面有一扇石门，上面刻着圣维特鲁维奥的面容，并刻有如下文字："没有人会永远迷失在暗影之中，即使在最深沉的夜里，烛光也会熠熠生辉"。

  • 这扇门通向隐藏圣物室（区域 10）。这里可以通过区域 4a 的绞盘打开。

圣维特鲁维奥节杖

[10] 隐藏圣物室

有两扇门连接着这扇门：一扇来自圣布伦娜之墓（区域 9 并通过区域 4a 开启），另一扇来自北部墓室（区域 6 并通过区域 4b 开启）。

在这个圆形墓室的中央，有一个未在燃烧的大火堆，以及几堆灰烬和一些烧焦的木头。一尊圣维特鲁维奥的雕像被放置于此，他的面前摆放着两支未点燃的蜡烛。他本人是一位身着盔甲的战士，头戴着有花纹的头盔。他的右侧是一把出鞘的巨剑，左侧是一面大盾。他的双手朝天，向面前的斜上方高举着圣维特鲁维奥节杖。

任何触碰圣维特鲁维奥雕像的角色都会听到自己的脑海里传来一个缥缈的声音，他说道：

"黑暗重压于人的内心。光明使人摆脱罪的重负。如果你想接过我的权杖，仅仅拥抱光明是不够的。"

"你必须点亮自己。"

那萨利尔·燧石

在墓穴中，@UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-core.items.Item.SceT000000000024]{圣维特鲁维奥节杖}的实际重量为 750 磅。但是，如果一个角色正在散发微光或明亮光照（魔法或非魔法光照）时，或者当一个角色与节杖完成同调时，节杖的重量只有 2 磅。

  • 角色可以通过职业特性或法术来完成这一要求，例如 光亮术， @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.nqBDWkVOfcGZt4YU]{妖火}，@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.MK6gpQMeDFo0cP9f]{不灭明焰 }或 @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.BP3GCwa66IAw1yTG]{昼明术}。这些法术的卷轴在教堂的其他区域可以被找到。如果这些法术一般只能对一个物品施放，让角色穿上或带上这件物品也可以实现以上要求。
  • 角色还可以把自己点燃。如果他这么做了，在每个他的回合开始时，他受到 1d6 点火焰伤害。
  • 一个握持或携带的光源，例如火把、蜡烛或者提灯都不能满足要求。
  • 角色可以尝试搬动或拖拽节杖，或者使用合适的法术来移动它（只要法术可以抬起 750 磅以上的物体）。
  • 如果有角色点燃了房间里的蜡烛和火堆，并在雕像前向神圣之火进行祷告，他的身体就会开始发光，他会散发出半径 10 尺的明亮光照，持续 1 小时。
  • 一名诗人、牧师、德鲁伊或圣武士可以花费一次短休的时间来和节杖同调。如果有角色这么做了，那就很适合让一支突击队在此时来到这里！

Eckerman Mill.name: Eckerman Mill
Eckerman Mill.text:
Eckerman Mill

Eckerman Mill is a dilapidated windmill that rests atop a lonely hill northwest of Drakkenheim. Its stone base is covered in moss and ivy, and the rotting wooden walls are riddled with holes. The entire structure creaks in the wind. The windmill blades still spin softly in the breeze, but the machinery within is damaged beyond repair and the millstone no longer turns. Scattered about the mill are the leftovers from countless expeditions. A well-used bonfire pit surrounded by a few well-worn logs for seating and several tattered tents are set up beside the mill. Abandoned here are a few bedrolls, battered cookware, a rusty chopping axe, and a waterlogged stack of wood.

  • The Mill is often used as a meeting place for adventurers venturing into Drakkenheim from the northwestern side of the Drann River. Since Emberwood Village lies several miles to the south on the opposite side of the river, many use Eckerman Mill as a makeshift campsite as it is much closer to the city proper.
  • Occasionally, faction agents who wish to avoid the eyes and ears of Emberwood Village arrange clandestine meetings here. In particular, the location is favoured by field surveyors dispatched by the Amethyst Academy.

Mill Graffiti

The mill is scrawled over with chalk graffiti and carvings, transforming the walls into an impromptu message board. There are several roughly engraved messages along the walls. Most list the names of dozens of would-be heroes who have ventured into the ruins, though many names are crossed out to mark those who did not return. Curiously, a few groups have not marked off a single casualty… perhaps they all made it out alive, or more likely, none survived. In addition to these memorials, along the wall one can find many dire warnings, cryptic riddles, poignant questions, crude maps to alleged treasure, and amateur drawings of horrible monsters encountered in the ruins.

  • Invite your player characters to write their own messages or names on the walls of Eckerman Mill, to follow the tradition of those who came before.
  • You can distribute one rumour to characters who examine the writings of Eckerman Mill to represent what they learn from reading the scrawled messages and riddles on the walls.

“This mill used to be my favourite stomping ground, now it's full of names of those who died. I gotta say, the novelty is wearing off quick.”

— Sebastian Crowe

Black Ivory Inn.name: 黑象牙酒馆
Black Ivory Inn.text:
Black Ivory Inn

“Listen, I know a guy, my cousin Mike used to run a smugglers tunnel underneath an old inn on the outskirts of town, leads ya right into the city. Now, I hear some people saying the old Black Ivory place is up and running again? Maybe worth seeing if that smugglers tunnel is still operational for an easy way in and out of the city!”

— Blackjack Mel

The Black Ivory Inn stands utterly pristine; apparently spared from the ravages of the meteor. Warm light, sweet-smelling wine, mirthful laughter, and stunningly beautiful piano melodies emanate from within and waft through the ruined streets nearby. However, the legendary music hall and hotel is the site of a bizarre arcane anomaly that has warped the fabric of time and space. Until the malignant abomination anchor- ing this twisted magic is destroyed, visitors to the Black Ivory Inn are trapped within a time loop: doomed to forever play out the last four hours and thirty-three minutes before the meteor struck.

“Magic is hard to control at the best of times. Sometimes you wish you could throw fire, and you end up setting yourself on fire. I know from experience. Look at this scar... arcane anomaly.”

— Sebastian Crowe

Overview

In this adventure, the characters must escape the time-cursed Black Ivory Inn with their lives and sanity intact. They may be drawn in by the mysterious melody coming from the disturbingly normal looking building, or they might seek out the Black Ivory Inn deliberately to find a missing contact or the smugglers passage rumoured to run underneath the hotel.

Adventure Hooks

A Haunting Melody. While travelling through Kingside, the player characters may hear piano music in the air, and the sounds of mirthful laughter. Following the music leads them to a pristine building, spared from the ravages of time and the meteor itself. Alternately the characters may hear about the inn and its music from a rumour, and may choose to investigate it on their own accord.

The Smugglers' Passage. In its heyday, the Black Ivory Inn was a notable speakeasy known for having an excellent smugglers' passage to move illegal goods into Drakkenheim under the walls. If this passage can be secured it may prove useful for navigating the more dangerous areas of the city.

Missing Prophet. A missing priest of the Falling Fire was sent to aid and recruit the rumoured people staying at the Inn, but has not returned. The party is asked to go investigate this disappearance and, if possible, bring the priest back to his people.

“Magic itself is unpredictable, not wielded but conjured with surprise. It all looks as wild as a boar.”

— Pluto Jackson

Interactions

The time loop is the result of a curious interaction between the Haze and a peculiarly worded wish.

Time Loop

A renowned musician performed here named Miss Charlotte. In her youth, Charlotte encountered an extraplanar entity that granted her a single wish. Her wish was to be the greatest living pianist of all time. However, Miss Charlotte was already an unparalleled musician. Instead of improving her talents, her wish granted her immortality by binding her life and talents to her piano, not unlike the relationship between a lich and its phylactery. As a result, she would perpetually remain the greatest living piano player of all time, so long as her piano remained intact.

Miss Charlotte was impaled by a delerium crystal during the destruction of Drakkenheim. She would have died if not for her wish. Caught between life and death, Miss Charlotte's wish has been twisted by the magic of the Haze, throwing the entire Black Ivory Inn into a temporal pocket that traps anyone who enters. Her body was transformed into a @UUID[Actor.BezicP0b3wmU2u4p], which now lurks below the temporal reflection of the Black Ivory Inn. Her mind projects a simulacrum of her original form that can continue playing her piano for all time.

Becoming Trapped

A character becomes trapped in the time loop the moment they wholly step inside the Black Ivory Inn. There is no saving throw.

  • Trapped creatures cannot perceive or interact with creatures and objects outside the Black Ivory Inn. This effect begins 10 ([[/r 3d6]]) minutes after the creature becomes trapped. During this period, victims can still perceive and interact with creatures outside Black Ivory Inn, but such creatures and objects appear hazy and faded before disappearing entirely. After this point, when a trapped creature looks outside the Black Ivory Inn, they see a time-lost version of Drakkenheim instead of the present-day ruins.
  • Characters trapped within the time loop are visible to outsiders only while they remain inside the Black Ivory Inn; they can't be perceived otherwise.

Effects of the Time Loop

The loop itself behaves like a pocket dimension or demiplane. The anomaly constantly plays out the last four hours and thirty-three minutes before the meteor struck in a time loop capturing the events from 3:40 PM to 8:13 PM on September 16th.

  • Characters are instantly killed by the meteor at the end of each loop at 8:13 PM.
  • After the death or incapacitation of the entire party (whether at the end of the loop or by some other means) they awaken again at 3:40 PM.
  • The characters are restored to full hit points and receive the benefits of a long rest. Any bodily damage is restored, no matter how severe. The characters retain whichever items were in their possession the moment they entered the Black Ivory Inn, but lose any items or equipment they picked up since then. As such, items that characters brought with them but used during the previous loop are restored!
  • Characters who consumed any food or drink within the Black Ivory Inn during the previous loop must succeed on a DC 10 Wisdom saving throw. On a failed saving throw, they temporarily lose their awareness of being stuck in a time loop until reminded by someone else what has happened to them.
  • Each time the time loop repeats or the characters are killed, each character must succeed on a DC 5 Intelligence saving throw or gain a random form of indefinite of Drakkenheim Madness.
  • Time continues to pass for those outside the loop. A creature trapped in the loop for over a year of real-world time loses their memories and becomes bound to the loop forever. They die and crumble to dust if the loop ends, and then may only be restored via a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.3okM6Gn63zzEULkz] spell.

Escaping the Loop

A character may escape the loop via @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.J6Jpw5XzB5aTeqnz] or @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.3okM6Gn63zzEULkz] but teleportation spells directed outside the demiplane fail. Characters might also be able to convince Miss Charlotte to let them leave.

Breaking the Loop

The time loop ends if the @UUID[Actor.BezicP0b3wmU2u4p] and the piano are both destroyed. When this happens the Black Ivory Inn and its patrons slowly erode into black ash. All that are left behind are the characters, and the five other visitors (or their corpses, if they did not survive the final loop). Little else remains of the Black Ivory Inn save rubble and ruin - it now appears as it should for a building struck by a meteor. There is a path through the rubble to the Smuggler's Warehouse below. The debris can be cleared away to re-open the underground tunnel.

Key Events

“Miss Charlotte is the greatest pianist of all time.”

  • The time loop begins at 3:40 PM
  • Miss Charlotte plays all afternoon into the evening.
  • At 7pm she takes a break from playing. She sits at the bar and chats with patrons, enjoying a glass of wine and a small meal for thirty minutes.
  • The meteor strikes at 8:13 PM, shortly after dusk. In this moment, a meteor chunk impales Miss Charlotte, no matter where she is located at that time.

  • There is a wash of dust and ash, and you open your eyes to thunderous applause as Charlotte finishes her first set.

Once inside the Black Ivory Inn, characters see Drakkenheim as it was fifteen years ago, in the late afternoon of September 16, 1111.

Miss Charlotte

Miss Charlotte is a willowy woman with slender limbs and delicate fingers. She wears a simple green gown, and keeps her hair tied in a bun behind her head. She gracefully plays the piano in an enraptured trance.

  • Ideal. To play music is all I've ever wanted, it's all I've ever had, it's everything I'll ever need, and the only thing I have left. Please don't take that from me.
  • Bond. Artists ought to be free to share their gifts with the world. I admire any artist who has the same passion and skill for their craft as I do for mine.
  • Flaw. I cannot bear what has happened, and the truth fills me with rage and anger. Instead, I will surround myself with music and mirth until the end of time.

Miss Charlotte and the piano are immune to all damage as long as the abomination has one hit point or more. In addition, as long as the abomination has at least one hit point, when Miss Charlotte fails a saving throw, she can choose to succeed instead.

When Miss Charlotte plays a chord on the piano (as an action), the abomination rejuvenates with all its hit points.

“I remember you… you caused a bit of trouble last time you were here. Just try to relax and enjoy the music.”

Tavern Patrons

Most patrons encountered within the Black Ivory Inn are hopelessly lost and cannot comprehend their current predicament. They are dimly aware of what is going on, but have endured so much madness it has crushed their actual will. Tales about meteors and time loops are met with laughter or bewilderment, which quickly turns to outrage and disgust if the player characters pursue it. Even proof such as delerium shards or uncanny foreknowledge fails to rouse them from their stupor.

  • There's roughly 35 ([[/r 10d6]]) human @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.SqZRuJ8lt2KGJBbq]{Commoners} or @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.GlaCGcgIP6YjBjGc]{Nobles} enjoying music, coffee, food, and accommodations at the Black Ivory Inn, with a staff of 7 ([[/r 2d6]]) more @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.SqZRuJ8lt2KGJBbq]{Commoners} who work as cooks, porters, and housekeepers alongside the notable figures below.
  • These people are forever lost to the time loop, and die when it ends. They never leave the inn, nor have any recollection or understanding of the time loop.
  • The tavern patrons defend Miss Charlotte if she's attacked. They can't perceive the @UUID[Actor.BezicP0b3wmU2u4p].

“Open” Mike Connolly. The owner of the Black Ivory Inn is a rotund human @UUID[Actor.RSVYdtx9l6jQkjiV] with blonde slicked back hair, a curly moustache and a set of round framed glasses, dressed in a red velvet coat. He is often found sitting close to the stage admiring the musicians. Though he knows about the illicit activities happening beneath his bar, he doesn't discuss the smuggler's tunnel openly with anyone he hasn't met before, but mentioning his young nephew Mel sparks his attention. Mike has the key to both the cellar doors and the smuggler's tunnel, which he keeps on a key ring on his belt.

Rogan Blum. The well-dressed bartender of the Black Ivory Inn is a human @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.13K3XK2A3wwxVKLD]. Rogan will listen to any tale of woe and regret from a paying customer, and his advice seems staggeringly insightful two or three drinks in.

Phifer Winters. A young human @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.SqZRuJ8lt2KGJBbq] serves drinks and coffee with a warm smile and a friendly compliment. Though she's often too busy working to chat, she'll excitedly talk about her aspirations to one day sail the Diamond Sea and travel to distant lands.

Reginald Grimes. This human @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.SqZRuJ8lt2KGJBbq] is approaching his seventies, but still cooks in the kitchen of the Black Ivory Inn. He takes great pride in his culinary work and is completely unable to tolerate criticism of his cooking. He deems each meal he makes a work of art.

Smuggler's Ring

A group of smugglers.

  • 3 ([[/r 1d6]]) @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.rb7OJt822wIO52qY]{Bandit Captains} and 14 ([[/r 4d6]]) @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.n4TEv7inVUkyZviN]{Bandits}.

Captain Wicket is a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.rb7OJt822wIO52qY] who has an old pirate hat and blue coat on. He is holding a meeting for his men about the next job they are doing in the basement meeting room in the Black Ivory Inn. He has three trusted commanders and a gang of thieves who have come to meet him here. He has requested that no one disturb their meeting. Detailed below is his crew:

  • Left Hand Lila: a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.rb7OJt822wIO52qY] with a hook for aright hand
  • Mr. Big: A gnome @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.rb7OJt822wIO52qY] with a devilish smirk and a knack for dramatic plans
  • Wind: an albino tiefling @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.rb7OJt822wIO52qY] with bright red eyes, black hair and huge horns
  • Ted Oats: a budding criminal with short black hair, eager for this job
  • Fred Oats: the twin brother of Ted with long black hair, defensive of his brother


Trapped Visitors

There are five people who have become trapped here recently whom the characters' actions may jolt back into awareness. Though they have forgotten themselves, they can be roused from their stupor by reminding them of present events.

Osiris Chronolly. A long-bearded and purple-robed Amethyst Academy @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.mQnsXanewsPiV7QE] who came to the Black Ivory Inn following a long-lost rumour that the legendary musician had gained her talents by making a wish. He, however, begrudgingly refuses any idea that he is trapped in a time loop unless some sort of irrefutable evidence can be placed before him. Once presented with proof, he speculates that breaking the loop will set recent arrivals free, but suspects those who were here when the time loop was created are lost forever.

Aaron Grint. This middle-aged @UUID[Actor.02VvEfOHseDs38Jm] of the Hooded Lanterns used to come to the Black Ivory Inn during his youth, and was a big fan of Miss Charlotte. He sits in a corner with his hood up smoking a pipe. He blissfully believes he has returned to his lost youth and has forgotten the horrors he witnessed in the Civil War. The return of his memories drives him into a rage.

Anika Patel. This human @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.D5UqYD1EnTrJaMTO] of the Silver Order devours meal after meal while enjoying the music. She has forgotten that she came to Drakkenheim to fight with the Silver Order, and now believes her oath is to protect Miss Charlotte. Anika is willing to help, but is bewildered by the idea of a time loop. It takes extreme convincing for her to accept the concept. Regardless, she stands up to quell any violence that breaks out in the tavern.

Balthazar Adamos. This human @UUID[Actor.jWBa5w2c7C1CY899] of the Falling Fire came to the Black Ivory Inn to investigate the haunting music. He doesn't drink, so he's maintained his memories through several loops already, and his inability to escape is driving him mad. Balthazar has now claimed a room upstairs and locked himself inside. He becomes crazed if someone mentions the time loop to him, but is terrified that ending the loop will mean his death. He came to Drakkenheim to participate in the Sacrament of the Falling Fire, and believes if he dies his soul will forever wander in darkness.

Fate Hope. A human @UUID[Actor.RSVYdtx9l6jQkjiV] clad in the colours of the Queen's Men, Fate arrived at the Black Ivory Inn looking for the smugglers tunnel. After talking to a few of the patrons, she sat at the bar to have a drink and lost her memories. She now spends each loop knocking back a few pints at the bar.

Area Details

Approach

From the outside, the Black Ivory Inn appears perfectly normal. The sounds of beautiful music can be heard from a block away and the lights are all on. The sounds of revelry and clanging glasses are heard within, drawing those who wander by towards the inn. The inn itself is a small square building two storeys tall with a porch that wraps fully around it. It has a sign hanging above the door that reads “Black Ivory Inn, Come for a drink, Stay for the company.”

Inn

The Piano Bar. Richly appointed with velvet curtains and gleaming varnished tables, each set with a candle in a glass bowl. Two well-dressed wait staff and the well-groomed bartender smile warmly.

Stage. Upon a candlelit stage in the far corner of the room stands a jet black piano with glistening white keys. Miss Charlotte is found here playing most of the time.

  • The piano has AC 15 and 30 hit points. It is immune to non-magical damage.

Kitchens and Pantries. Most of the meals served at the Black Ivory Inn were prepared foods purchased from local bakers, farmers, and butchers.

Scullery. Washing rooms for laundry.

Inn Rooms. Several comfortable inn rooms each with two beds, a chest of drawers, a small table, and an armchair. Several also include a wardrobe or baths. A common privy on each floor is kept clean and fresh.

Basement

Storage Cellar. This mundane cellar is stocked with a few kegs of ale, and has a large wall filled with fine wines of various ages and assortments. Most of them are Crownland wines from the north vineyard of Drakkenheim. Many jars and crates of preserved foods and dried fruits and berries can also be found, along with sacks of grains and flour, and a few household tools and appliances. At the back of the cellar is an old oak door with a padlock on it.

Gambling Den. This room is clearly appointed for preparing smuggling operations and as a place for secret communication, planning, or illegal gambling to take place. The room is sparse of decorations save for a few round tables and some of the older stools from upstairs. The tables are laid out with decks of cards, bottles of booze, and even a map pinned on the wall that details the underground passages, smugglers' tunnels and sewer systems of Drakkenheim. Currently there is a private meeting happening down here between Captain Wicket and his squad. One of the bandit captains stands at the door to make sure they aren't disturbed as they lay out plans for smuggling a rare painting into Drakkenheim to sell to a fence procuring rare art for a local exhibit. The crew are hostile towards unwanted guests and tell any who come near that they are having a private meeting and they best go back upstairs before they start trouble.

Smuggler's Warehouse. The Smuggler's Warehouse is in disarray. There are smashed crates and a spray of gold coins across the floor. A shelf along the wall has toppled over and splintered along the ground. Along the far wall is an inconspicuous set of thick wooden doors that are locked with a large padlock. In the corner of the room is the @UUID[Actor.BezicP0b3wmU2u4p]. It is a massive mound of flesh occupying the upper corner of the room, with sticky fleshy tendrils clinging to the various walls and surfaces around it. It looks like it's spreading outwards towards the door - it has grown and caked over the smuggler's tunnel doors almost completely, and one can make out bits of debris, wood, and gold that have been enveloped by the spreading horror.

  • Stuck in the side of the creature is the remnant of a grand piano, and on the front of the creature one can make out a feminine face, twisted in horror, with glowing octarine eyes and a gaping mouth. The abomination has several other eyes and mouths around it that all moan and cry as one approaches. Its' eyes become fixed on anyone who enters the room.

Underground Tunnel. The smuggler's tunnel is a long straight tunnel that goes on as far as one can see. It is lined with occasional torches.

  • A small satchel hanging on the wall has a scroll of @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.CAxSzHWizrafT033] and a scroll of @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.spells.Item.1nhIxh0DsJsntCfj].
  • The tunnel connects to the Old Town cistern beneath Slaughterstone Square.

“In the deepest parts of the city, the Haze is as thick as pea soup...if only it tasted like it.”

— Veo Sjena

Time-Lost Streets

A trapped victim exiting the Black Ivory Inn enters into an illusory version of Drakkenheim as it was fifteen years ago. Once victims travel out of line of sight of the Black Ivory Inn, they immediately appear back before the inn again as if the streets themselves looped back around. All the doors and windows of all the buildings seem to open into a crudely rendered room, but when entered, a character appears back in the taproom of the Black Ivory Inn.

The folk walking the streets are merely phantasms with dim awareness. They repeat only a few short phrases such as “Lovely day today, isn't it.” “Strange thing in the sky, that.” or “I'll be on my way, then…” If attacked or damaged, theydie, and the others scream and run.

Developments

Check out anytime you'd like. With the protean abomination destroyed, the inn returns to the state it was meant to be in. The creature dissolves into nothing but a pile of goo and within it rests a chunk of meteoric iron with 2d4 fragments of delerium embedded in it. The ceiling of the inn has mostly collapsed from the impact and a clear hole in the floor leads directly into the basement where the abomination lay. The inn lies in shambles, another nondescript ruin of Drakkenheim. But, the entrance to the smugglers tunnel is still very much intact, and Open Mike's corpse can be found amongst the bodies of the patrons. The key to the smuggler's tunnel is safely fastened on his belt.

A Safe Passage. The smuggler's tunnel now lays open to the players. The players can choose to use this tunnel that leads them directly to the cistern below Slaughterstone Square without provoking a random encounter. They come out from an inconspicuous grate in the floor of the cistern that the monsters of Drakkenheim seem to have overlooked. Once there, the sewers function as normal.

Thankful Pilgrim. If he survives, the priest is endlessly thankful to be rid of the Black Ivory Inn and to still be alive and offers the party a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.aDHRuUs29SrumWfq] or an @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.TZggpdbOYqOCG7mY]. He asks if they would accompany him to Saint Selina's Monastery. He would most like to introduce them to @UUID[Actor.tqJK1mzxPst0xV08] and speak highly of their courageous and heroic deeds. He latches on to the characters, believing them to be the prophesied heroes that the book of Falling Fire spoke of.

Friendly Factions. The other survivors are all a little dazed from their time spent in the inn, confused and in shock of the grim reality they have just been awoken into. They all thank the characters and agree to speak highly of them to their leaders and commanders. If the characters made enemies of any of the survivors, or if they boldly helped them or rescued them, those stories are brought back to the factions they represented.

Rat's Nest Tavern.name: 鼠窝酒馆
Rat's Nest Tavern.text:
鼠窝酒馆

“我的同事手头有个实验，但他需要一块大的妄质水晶。小碎片是不行的。可惜，这种样本在外城的废墟中非常罕见。不过，我们手头现在有了一个线索……”

陨星的一小部分在空中裂开，坠落在了废墟蔓生区的鼠窝酒馆，它完全摧毁了这里的大部分建筑。不过，这也让一颗完好无缺的妄质水晶被留了下来。但是，一群鼠怪在酒馆地下室下挖了一个洞穴，把陨石搬进了它们的巢穴里。鼠怪还愈发胆大妄为，他们对废墟发动了突袭，并在此过程中抓走了几个俘虏。

总览

在这场冒险中，角色们要前往鼠窝酒馆取得妄质水晶或营救被监禁的囚徒。他们可以与鼠怪战斗、偷偷潜入或者以交涉欺骗鼠怪，但是鼠怪会依靠埋伏和陷阱毫不留情地保卫自己的巢穴。

冒险引子

前景可期： (紫晶学院) 川流联系了角色们，准备和他们进行一次秘密会面。她想让他们从鼠窝中取回一块妄质水晶。这种大小的妄质晶体通常价值约 1000gp，但她愿意支付 1250gp。

  • @UUID[Actor.1p6ksQrMvxCBPkga] 的情报来源于酒馆是被原陨星的碎片摧毁的传言。由于她的情报是基于推测，因此她为角色们每人准备了 1 瓶@UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.equipment.Item.phbagPotionofHea] ，以防他们最终一无所获。
  • 川流不能透露实验的内容：

“知道什么该做什么不该做，这样我们之间的雇佣关系才可以持续下去。”

下落不明： (覆影明灯) @UUID[Actor.zAumxn18Z0GTvBbL] 在烬木村找到角色们。他的妹妹@UUID[Actor.Yry1g6heIrVxK7xN] 在昨晚的一次补给行动中遭到鼠怪的伏击，被它们掳走了。他需要角色们在为时已晚之前救出@UUID[Actor.Yry1g6heIrVxK7xN]。他为此悬赏 250gp，并希望 @UUID[Actor.Yry1g6heIrVxK7xN] 能平安归来。

  • 安松违背了撤退指令，追踪鼠怪到了鼠窝。在鼠怪用一枚受污染的投石索弹丸打伤了他后，他被迫撤退。安松解释说，鼠怪经常会留下俘虏，以便日后可以享用“新鲜的食物”。因此他确信佩特拉还活着。
  • 安松警告角色们那里存在污染的危险。他无法亲自帮助角色们，因为他自己也正在治疗污染。他建议他们，如果在废墟中受到污染，烬木村的圣火守护者汉娜可以用魔法帮助他们。
  • 最后，他答应自己会因为角色们的帮助为他们向总司令美言几句。不过，他强调这终归是一项私人工作——他已经在冒着抗命的风险了：

“作为覆影明灯的成员，我们的生存法则就是不能冒生命危险去尝试‘徒劳’的救援。我们在准备加入组织时都知道这很危险，但她是我妹。”

互动

大多数情况下，洞穴里的鼠怪对任何闯入者都充满敌意。它们知道谁住在洞穴里，谁住在洞穴外，并能通过气味辨认出对方。它们会引诱入侵者进入陷阱或埋伏，然后鼠怪们就可以利用自己的数量优势发起攻击。鼠怪在夜间最为活跃，三分之二的鼠怪会离开洞穴外出觅食。在白天，除了少数的哨兵外，大多数鼠怪都会在洞穴中睡觉。

鼠王子

洞穴里的鼠怪由一只高大凶猛的鼠怪所领导，他自封为 @UUID[Actor.wguXXOlJxvHZw7xo] (见 附录 A)。他之所以能统治洞穴是因为他在所有鼠怪中最大、最强壮，而且他还杀死了上一只敢自称鼠王子的鼠怪。他相信，一旦他的鼠群有了足够的食物，他们就能长得更大，繁殖得更多。到那时，所有其他鼠怪都得臣服于他！

  • 个人特点： 鼠王子像个暴君一样欺压着其他人。在说话时，鼠王子会把话重复两三次以示强调。“是的是的是的 （Yesyesyes）……”
  • 理想：鼠王子热爱杀戮、进食、繁殖和睡觉。而且基本就是这个顺序。
  • 牵绊： 鼠王子头戴一顶做工粗糙的王冠，声称自己是德拉肯海姆所有鼠怪的统治者。虽然这与事实相去甚远，但如果要试图说服鼠王子不是这样的，那就只能祝那个人好运了。
  • 缺陷： 逻辑条理会让鼠王子感到难以理解和愤怒，除非逻辑中含有食物相关的内容。

如果鼠王子独自被生擒，他会试图逃跑或为了活命而求饶，他会给予他能想到的任何东西来说服角色们放自己一条生路。

先知吱吱

这只白化鼠怪 @UUID[Actor.N47wmcUojv25nJTo] 是这群鼠怪的精神领袖。

  • 个性特点：她会编造许多关于鼠神的怒火和精明的奇幻故事
  • 理想：鼠神希望鼠怪吃掉任何他们能吃的东西。而这给予了她魔法能力去帮助鼠怪们获取食物和“亮闪闪”（妄质）。总有一天，鼠神会吞噬整个世界。其他鼠怪都觉得这太美妙了
  • 牵绊：她觉得收集亮闪闪（妄质）可以取悦她的鼠神，并以他之名举行同族相食的仪式。鼠怪热爱进食，所以他们也热爱这个仪式。
  • 缺陷：她觉得她可以通过妄质水晶和鼠神对话。她将水晶保存在她自己的窝（区域 8）里，并且会在其他鼠怪碰它时勃然大怒。

和鼠怪交朋友

在原版的 德拉肯海姆之墟 战役中，鼠王子向我的角色们投降了。角色们欺骗了他，让他相信角色们是鼠神派来的鬼魂，于是鼠王子与玩家角色结为了好友，并成为了一个经常登场的 NPC。角色们会继续保护和隐藏鼠怪，但是一旦豺狼人被赶出了城市，鼠怪的数量就会越来越多。如果全放任不管，鼠怪的数量会膨胀到一个非常庞大的程度，甚至有可能吞噬整座城市！

区域详述

枯槁巷

鼠窝酒馆位于牧羊者之路南面泥泞不堪、乱石遍布的枯槁巷里，坐落在破烂不堪的出租屋和摇摇欲坠的公寓楼之间。原本酒馆的部分几乎已经完全被夷为平地，附近的建筑也遭到了严重的破坏，剩下的只有堆满瓦砾的石头地基。酒馆一楼的墙壁约到胸口高，有几根支撑柱向酒馆外延伸开，就像裂开的肋骨。酒馆的屋顶和上层已经完全坍塌，变成了一个被碎石覆盖、雾气弥漫的大坑。原来的酒馆招牌从街道对面的一栋建筑中斜伸出来。招牌上篆刻着一只躺在一盘食物上，正在微笑的肥鼠。

  • 搜索了街道附近的下水道出入口的角色可以发现一条从下水道通往鼠穴的隐秘入口。

酒馆遗址

在残存的酒馆内，木质地板已经几乎全部坍塌，在地上形成了一个巨大的缺口。这里到处散落着滚落的砖块、灰化的木渣、烧焦的瓦片、碎裂的木板和支撑梁，破损的家具、杯子、碎玻璃，还有零星的骨头和餐具。

  • 通往地下室的大洞就在地面之下 10 尺深处。
  • 通过调查或求生（DC 10） 检查该区域可能会发现类似动物的抓痕、啃痕、粗皮毛的碎块、泥泞的足迹和老鼠粪便。

[1] 地下室坑洞

地下室的石墙一片焦黑。碎石和瓦砾围绕着一个直径 15 尺、深 5 尺的泥泞大坑堆砌着。坑里闪烁着微弱的异色的光芒。

  • 检查大坑去寻找光芒的来源，就可以发现 1d6 块妄质晶屑（每块价值 10gp）。在坑的中央有一块约莫 1 尺宽的明显的石头凹痕，就好像曾有一大块石头被人挖了出来一样。如果这里真的曾有一块陨石，那它现在已经不见了。
  • 鼠怪从坑里搬走了一大块融合了妄质水晶的石头，并将其拖进了先知地穴（区域 8）。求生（DC 10）检定可以发现一些拖拽的痕迹、泥泞的足迹和几只野兽的爪印，这表明最近有重物从坑口被移走了。
  • 调查 (DC 10), 或拥有泥瓦匠/石匠工具熟练。墙上的破洞不是因为陨石撞击导致的。这条通道是最近被人为挖掘出来的。

鼠穴

以下情况适用于鼠穴内的大部分区域：

隧道：这条被挖掘出来的隧道里布满填土、粘土、松散的泥土和碎石。狭窄的通道宽 5 到 10 尺，高度基本不超过 6 尺。中等体型的生物必须弯着腰才能在隧道通行。隧道蜿蜒曲折，忽左忽右，上下起伏。

穴室： 较大的房间足有 8 到 10 尺高。大部分房间的内部都很干燥，但脚下却铺满了难以辨认的污秽物、骨头碎片、毛皮和布屑，还有树叶和草屑。

光照： 鼠怪的视力依靠黑暗视觉，所以隧道里面没有光源。

声音和气味：地下的空气潮湿，散发着一 股老鼠粪尿的臭味。吱吱的叫声和叽叽喳喳的交流声在隧道里此起彼伏。

[2] 设陷的入口隧道

这条泥泞的通道大约有 8 尺宽。它陡峭地向下延伸了 10 尺，然后向左急转。

  • 调查 (DC 10)： 这里潮湿的土壤很湿滑，很容易让人摔跤。

滑道陷阱： 没有攀爬速度的角色在从入口通道向下移动时，必须通过一个 DC 12 的敏捷豁免，否则就会滑倒在泥泞的通道上。使用了绳索的角色在豁免时具有优势。豁免失败的角色会倒地 prone 并立即滑下通道，然后被困在监视者地穴（区域 3）的落穴陷阱中。

[3]] 监视者地穴

窸窸窣窣的声音和叽叽喳喳的鼠叫声充斥着这个泥泞的土穴。

  • 2只 @UUID[Actor.yFc1bSbhRbCHjRFs]{暗袭鼠怪} 和 6 @UUID[Actor.v6osXCahFwmobuQz]{鼠怪} 在这里看守着。他们每只鼠都带有一张弩和几瓶准备好的@UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.equipment.Item.phbagAlchemistsF]。

落穴陷阱： 在设陷的入口隧道（区域 2）底部的地面上被挖出了一个 10 尺深的尖刺落穴陷阱。陷坑被一块固定在坑洞边缘的大布覆盖，并用泥土和碎石伪装了起来。一个感知检定（DC 10）可以发现这个陷坑。任何移动到布上的人都会掉入坑中，摔到底部那些被削尖的木刺上，并受到来自木刺的 5([[/r 2d4]])点穿刺伤害和 5([[/r 1d10]])点坠落伤害。陷坑的边缘湿滑，很难逃脱。爬出陷阱需要进行一次 DC 10 的运动检定。如果检定结果低于 DC 5点或更多，该生物就会掉回尖刺上。

  • 陷阱的底部生活着一个 @UUID[Compendium.dnd-monster-manual.actors.Actor.mmSwarmOfRats000] 它们会噬咬任何掉入坑中的人。鼠群会攻击坑中的任何生物，并将其作为食物。

[4] 鼠怪巢穴

这个小洞穴里有一个用长草、干草、泥巴、树枝和树叶做成的 杯状巢穴，里面铺着碎布条、毛皮碎片、皮革碎片、纸张和各种闪闪发光的小饰品。

  • 有8只 @UUID[Actor.v6osXCahFwmobuQz]{鼠怪} and 1只 @UUID[Actor.yFc1bSbhRbCHjRFs] 各自在自己零散分布在洞穴系统之中的巢穴中.
  • 鼠怪囤积了一些小饰品作为个人财宝，外加一小片妄质或一个装有 10([[/r 3d6]])gp 的袋子。其中一个巢穴里有一瓶 @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.equipment.Item.phbagPotionofHea]。

[5] 食品藏匿处

在这个散发着馊味的洞穴里，杂乱无章地摆放着各种最近拾获的动物尸体、残肢断臂还有其他不堪入目的东西。

  • 鲜肉必须时刻保持供应，所以偶尔会有囚犯被绑在这里，以便稍后就能吃上新鲜的肉食
  • 宝藏： 北边的藏匿处有一套盗贼工具，一套制毒工具，一套草药工具，还有2瓶 @UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.equipment.Item.phbagPotionofHea]。
  • 南边的储藏间关押着一名还活着的囚犯——覆影明灯的@UUID[Actor.Yry1g6heIrVxK7xN]（一位@UUID[Actor.02VvEfOHseDs38Jm]{城市游侠 }）。她没有武器，受了伤（剩余 20 HP），并且已经用完了所有的法术位。不过，如果有武器的话，她愿意自食其力逃出这里。角色们可以通过她的斗篷和服装认出她是覆影明灯的士官。如果她活了下来，她会请求角色们帮助她回到牧者门。她其实可以自己过去，但她希望角色们能去见见她的同袍们。

[6] 鼠神神像

这间密室里有一个用碎石、泥巴和老鼠粪便制作而成的臃肿肥胖的邪恶老鼠雕像，雕像上用两块妄质碎片当做它的眼睛。雕像脚下散落着各种祭品——头骨、骨块、匕首、腐肉碎块，还有更小的妄质碎片。雕像前摆放着一个用普通石板砌成的沾满鲜血的祭坛。

  • 6只 @UUID[Actor.v6osXCahFwmobuQz] 正在神像前祈祷。如果有入侵者来到这里，它们会立刻逃跑求救。
  • 宝藏： 神像的眼睛是 2 块妄质晶片（每块价值 100gp）。[[/r 1d6]]块妄质晶屑散落在神像周围。有一些卷轴被放在神像前——@UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.spells.Item.phbsplBane000000]{灾祸术}，@UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.spells.Item.phbsplFaerieFire]{妖火} 和@UUID[Compendium.dnd-players-handbook.spells.Item.phbsplInflictWou]{致伤术} 。

[7] 集会巢穴

在这间臭气熏天的密室中，干草堆和兽皮环绕着一堆明亮的篝火。

  • T鼠王子经常在这里和其他6只 @UUID[Actor.v6osXCahFwmobuQz] 一起狂欢。
  • 鼠怪会在这里聚会，商讨他们那些邪恶又不靠谱的计划。这个房间里有几套工具，包括一套修补工具和一套炼金工具，鼠怪们用这些工具制造临时武器和简易炸药。
  • 这条洞穴的通道直接通向下水道。如果鼠怪们受到伤害或无法再保护自己的巢穴，它们就逃到这里然后开始四散奔逃

[8] 先知地穴

在这个宽敞的房间里，有一个又大又豪华的篮子做的窝。在这个窝上铺着用碎布、树枝和树叶缝制的帆布。窝前有一个粗糙的石头基座，基座上放着一大块约一尺宽的银色石头。石头的表面则镶嵌着一块突出的妄质水晶。

  • 先知吱吱 的巢穴就在这里。她有一只老鼠形态的@UUID[Compendium.dnd-monster-manual.actors.Actor.mmImp00000000000]{小魔鬼} ，而它的真身则像一只恶心的带翼且无毛的老鼠。
  • 妄质水晶就在这里，但它被卡在了一块岩石中：一块由酒馆地下室的石头、融化的泥土和陨石组合而成的石头。鼠怪把它搬走并带到了这里，因为他们自己无法将水晶从岩石中取出。这块石头重约50 磅。

发展

成功探索鼠窝的角色可能会触发以下进展：

妄质水晶

川流会忠实地履行自己的诺言。如果角色们在和她的交易中表现得迅速而专业，她会给予他们一瓶 @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-core.items.Item.AquT000000000000] 作为额外奖励。她建议他们好好休息几天来恢复一下体力，并承诺很快（[[/r 1d6]]天后）就会联系他们，并向他们提供另一份委托。话分两头，如果角色们没能找到妄质水晶，川流对他们的印象就会大打折扣。她仍然愿意向角色们购买他们找到的妄质晶体，但她会决定先等一等并重新评估角色们的能力后再给他们提供新的工作。

还没有与紫晶学院接触的角色手中仍握有一个重要的发现，这让他们可能会与任何派系的人接触。覆影明灯知道妄质水晶价值不菲，但他们也很乐意让角色们留着它，作为对他们努力的额外奖励。安松或佩特拉会建议角色在烬木村把水晶卖给晴日贸易出口公司。其他NPC 可能会建议角色们在村子里四处打听一下紫晶学院或女王的弟兄们的联系人，把水晶卖给他们。亦或者，角色可能会遇到一位白银骑士团的骑士，他会鼓励角色们摧毁妄质水晶。最后，天火信众可能会宣称水晶有神圣的用途，并试图说服角色们将水晶作为祭品带给圣赛莉娜修道院的卢克雷蒂亚·马西亚斯。

救出佩特拉·朗

如果佩特拉·朗幸存，她会邀请角色们一起返回牧者门。她的同袍们都为她的平安归来而激动不已，艾利亚斯·德雷克希尔总司令也会注意到这些角色。他暂时不会亲自接见他们，而是安排安松或佩特拉在 7([[/r 2d6]])天内联系他们，让他们去执行另一项任务。

安松会提醒角色们，他们之间的委托是个人私事，严格来说并不属于覆影明灯的官方工作。因此，仅凭这次任务并不能让角色们在牧者门自由通行。不过，如果角色们在紧急情况下来到牧者门，覆影明灯会帮助他们。在这种情况下，他们会忽略这里的通行条例并说“仅此一次”，然后让他们通过。

如果角色们没能救出佩特拉，安松就会认为他们是一群废物。他会对是否要让他们进一步参与覆影明灯的任务而产生犹豫，并在未来的任何时候都会对他们的能力深感不信任

如果佩特拉死了，而角色们还没有与覆影提灯成为盟友，那就得看他们是否有告诉覆影明灯佩特拉的经历了。无论如何，她的战友们都会对她的失踪和死亡感到震惊。伤心之余，铁石心肠的总司令再也不会提起她。安松则会继续前行，但他总觉得他失去了一部分的自己。

“This place was a dive before the meteor. Infested with rats, terrible ale. Honestly, maybe it's been improved?”

— Sebastian Crowe

 

“I knew it was a dive bar but I didn't think I would fall head first into an actual rats' nest.”

— Pluto Jackson

Reed Manor.name: 苇叶宅邸
Reed Manor.text:
Reed Manor

“Oscar Yoren had irreconcilable differences with the Academy. I'm not privy to all the details, but the Directorate cut support for his research. When Yoren absconded with several volumes on conjuration, transmutation, and necromancy, we discovered he'd taken up unsavoury methods for acquiring “raw materials'' instead. He was declared malfeasant, and sought refuge in Drakkenheim. He's survived in the city ruins for about a decade since. We don't understand how he has managed to do so, but we want to find out. He knows something about the Haze.”

— River

Reed Manor stands in a now-dilapidated upper-class residential neighbourhood on the north side of Drakkenheim, just off College Road. The fate of the original occupants is unknown, but it is now occupied by the malfeasant wizard @UUID[Actor.jfJGagVOoUgyCyxn] and his apprentices.

Overview

In this adventure, the characters encounter @UUID[Actor.jfJGagVOoUgyCyxn]. Yoren has developed valuable research about the Haze and delerium, but the mage is not necessarily willing to share his discoveries freely. Most notably, Yoren has developed a formula for brewing @UUID[Compendium.drakkenheim-core.items.Item.AquT000000000001], a potion that offers protection from contamination (see Appendix D). Characters must decide how they'll deal with Oscar Yoren: they may bargain with him to obtain his research, steal his work through stealth and trickery, or attack the mage and destroy his experiments. Depending on the characters' actions, Oscar Yoren could become a recurring character in the campaign.

Adventure Hooks

Stolen Homework. @UUID[Actor.1p6ksQrMvxCBPkga] hires the characters to obtain Oscar Yoren's Research. She offers the characters a reward of 250 gold, and one magic item crafted by the Amethyst Academy — a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.44XNWmMGnwXn7bNW] made from a delerium shard.

  • “We located Oscar Yoren by trailing a group of expelled students who sought him out. They may be working as his apprentices now.”

  • “We don't care what you have to do to obtain this information, but you must bring back something tangible: a spellbook, his journals, or samples of his work. In the worst case scenario… all we require is his brain.”


Potions Inspectors

“For several years now, we've been buying potions from a man named Oscar Yoren. He's a bit of a strange recluse, but his work is reliable and he doesn't seem to be bothering anyone. His potions are much cheaper than what the Amethyst Academy charges. Normally, he sends one of his apprentices to Shepherd's Gate every Monday with a new shipment, but they didn't arrive last week. The week before we got half the normal order. Worse, we've discovered that several of the potions we previously received simply didn't work, and a few were even contaminated. Something's going on, and we'd like you to investigate.”

— Petra Lang

Lieutenant @UUID[Actor.Yry1g6heIrVxK7xN] (or @UUID[Actor.zAumxn18Z0GTvBbL]) contacts the characters in Emberwood Village. She offers the characters 250 gold pieces for the task. Furthermore, the Hooded Lanterns will offer characters a weapon from their stockpile: either a +1 longsword or a +1 longbow.

  • “Our past dealings with Yoren have generally been positive, but it's possible that he cleans up his operation whenever we come around to check on him.”

  • “We're worried about these faulty and contaminated potions, and we need you to make sure Oscar Yoren isn't cutting corners. “

  • “However, if something happened to him, we need to know. We still need Oscar Yoren's potions. We don't have access to a lot of our own magic, and we're stretched pretty thin right now, especially with several sick Lanterns.”

  • “He lives in an old house on the north end of town, I guess he uses some kind of magic to keep himself healthy. We think he might have been kicked out of the Amethyst Academy, but that's their business, not ours.”

If the player characters don't take this mission, Petra dispatches a group of @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.O3ABqI55Ir1du1Xa]{Scouts} instead. They show up while the characters are exploring the manor.

The Buyout

“The greencloaks have a supplier who's been making potions for ‘em at a pretty steep discount. He's some sort of cast-off from the Academy. A guy like that can be a valuable asset… my employer would like to acquire this asset. That's where you come in. Make him an offer he can't refuse.”

— Blackjack Mel

@UUID[Actor.btuo8mywkRo5g6M9] invites the characters to meet him at the Skull & Sword Taphouse in Emberwood Village. He wants the characters to convince Oscar Yoren to break ties with the Hooded Lanterns and start providing potions for the Queen's Men instead. He offers the characters 250 gold as payment, plus some “fancy new shoes” — @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.hSY1b8yi8JWw2blf].

  • “Rough him up, but don't kill him. He's gotta be able to work.”

  • “We want the same price he's giving the greencloaks, but he has to cut them off. As long as he delivers the goods, the Queen of Thieves can provide all the protection he needs. If he refuses, we'll break his legs and steal his work.”

Interactions

Oscar Yoren

This malfeasant wizard fled the Amethyst Academy ten years ago.
